pages.text: Devices that perform actions in the world usually require energy to operate.\pBut Redstone Control machines can't store energy themselves. Instead, whenever a device needs energy to perform an action, it will try to drain it from the energy storage device it is $(l:connecting)connected to$(/l) and fail the action if it can't be supplied instantly.

The same principle also applies to generators. This means, you can't connect a machine directly to a generator, there always has to be storage in between!\pSince storage devices are passive they can't be connected to each other directly either. Instead you can use a \iTransformer\d to continuously transfer power between them.

pages.title: Storage
pages.text: \iBattery Cells\d form a connected structure when placed next to each other within the same block and every exposed face can be turned into a power port by right-clicking it with a \iPower Cable\d. You can also create one data port on it for charge readout.\pYou can also use external Forge Energy compatible blocks for storage by $(l:io#resource)connecting them via \iPower Ports\d$(/l).

pages.title: Generators
pages.text: Currently there are only \iSolar Cells\d which generate energy from sunlight. They need a clear view to the sky and the power output varies over the day based on the sun's angle.\nThese can also form a connected structure but with only one power port.
